lesson.name: Unit 3: Part 3: Real-Life Scenarios and Bright Ideas for Teaching

page.title: Real-Life Scenarios
page.contents:
Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_3230.mp3

Audio Transcript


Many students still learning English have solid work experience and considerable background knowledge related to jobs and careers that interest them. But they may lack the English skills to understand explanations and contribute ideas. Illustrations and sketches can help you get your point across, and the same process can help your students communicate ideas. The video will show you how this is done. Mike, teaching a group of displaced workers, illustrates a construction problem (“My patio needs work”), using a technique called Chalk Talk. He then invites students to draw ideas for the project they will undertake in a couple of weeks—fixing up and renovating a broken-down school on the Mexican side of the southern U.S. border. Notice that the students have picture dictionaries that they can consult as they sketch out the “before” picture (namely, the renovation problems they may encounter) and then illustrate the “after” picture (what the school might look like after the workers completed the work). This has always been one of my favorite projects.

From Mike’s Class Does Chalk Talk [Videofile] by James Powrie, 2006, Las Cruces, NM: Literacywork International.

Copyright 2006 by Literacywork International. Retrieved from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KB7KhIp0OjY.

American Institutes for Research used with permission from Literacywork International.

You are teaching in a bridge program for a career cluster related to construction. Your students have not worked in the trades, but most have done jobs around the house. You want to start where students’ interests lie and build on what they know.

Bright Idea: Illustrate the Process

  • Select an everyday problem related to work around the house or in the community.
  • Sketch the problem on the board. Involve students as you draw and talk.
  • Present students with a related problem and ask them to work in teams to sketch a problem and solution.
  • Invite students to explain their sketches and share them with the group.

page.title: From Personal Experience to Job Tasks
page.contents:
Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_3230.mp3

Audio Transcript


In the video, you saw Mike use a problem with his patio as a jumping-off point for dividing a construction problem into a problem and a solution. You can use a similar approach with other work-related problems. To start, you might select an occupation or a profession that relates to students’ everyday interactions and experiences. Consider professions such as heating, vacuum, and air conditioning professional; computer support; medical office specialist; or child care provider. Consider also the trades (e.g., maintenance, computer repair, plumbing, groundskeeping). Then create a table that invites students to identify a problem, determine what needs to be done, and list the materials and tools needed to do the job.

  1. Think of an occupation-related situation and brainstorm ideas for handling it (e.g., a patient cannot find her insurance card; water is flooding an apartment; the air conditioner is broken; a child in daycare seems to have a fever).

  1. Download the Word document and fill it in with ideas (either by yourself or with your students).

  1. Look at the attached sample lesson on changing an air conditioning filter as inspiration for a contextualized lesson.

page.title: Bright Idea: Put Students to Work
page.contents:
Image: Permission granted by Juan Carlos Aguirre,
Director of Continuing Education, South Texas College.
  1. Provide students with a list of key terms in English and in Spanish (students can work as a group to translate).
  2. Use an online tool, such as QUIA, to create flash cards related to medical terminology you use in your course. Ask students to work in pairs to practice saying the words and discussing their meaning.
  3. Invite students to create materials for the class (e.g., a team of students researches one body system and explains it to the class).

Resources: If you are new to project-based learning (PBL), consider exploring the attached guide for ideas.

page.title: Scenario: Entrepreneurship Skills
page.contents:
You have a mixed class of students at the high beginning to low intermediate level. All the students want job-related English, but their career goals are not quite clear yet. A number of the students are interested in what they should know about being entrepreneurs.

Questions:

  • What experience do my students and their families have selling products or services?
  • What events have they organized that required entrepreneurial thinking?
  • What tasks or projects could I create to have students envision a small business and market it to the community?
  • What resources on entrepreneurship are available to me and my students (textbooks, online videos, Small Business Bureau materials)?

page.title: Bright Idea: Showing Entrepreneurs in Action
page.contents:
The website We Are  New York includes an episode, called The Wedding that shows different groups of immigrant entrepreneurs. These immigrants spring into action when other vendors for a wedding have cancelled.

The video highlights the importance of being prepared at a moment’s notice, keeping up on your skills, double-checking information, and working as a team.

Feel free to simply dip into the video and preview the content to decide if it might fit into your class.

page.title: Scenario: Students are Interested in Creating Digital Materials
page.contents:
You are teaching a course with a digital literacy component. You students are interested in using digital photographs and videos for presentations. The class wants to produce a series of how-to videos that illustrate what they know and what they can do.

Bright Idea:

  • Discuss the use of digital work with your students. and engage students in planning and executing a project
  • Take advantage of your students’ talents and experience and invite them to share skills.
  • Consider inviting a technical person to conduct a workshop to guide your students on the use of digital tools

page.title: Scenario: Too Much Information
page.contents:
Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_3250.mp3

Audio Transcript


To help your students manage textbook reading, you may first need to familiarize yourself with the way the information in modern training textbooks is organized and laid out. You may want to borrow a few books for a field your students are interested in and explore the books’ structure. You can then start to think about what tasks you can create to familiarize students with the structure of the book. You may consider variations of a treasure hunt that leads students to different portions of the book and its chapters, such as table of contents, glossary, or major and minor headings. You may also notice that textbooks often contain charts and graphs, and may think of activities that teach strategies useful for analyzing and interpreting this kind of presentation. For example, you may draw students’ attention to the title of a graph and its source, invite them to discuss the information, and then tell the story represented in a graph in text form. To build background knowledge in understanding statistical data, try introducing your students to appropriate infographics.

Your students seem overwhelmed by the amount of information contained in books and other materials used in the technical classes. They have trouble with complex handouts and cannot make sense of the layout of some of the textbook pages. They are often unsure where they should start reading and give up.

page.title: Bright Idea: Deconstructing Texts Using Infographics
page.contents:
Learning how to take apart and analyze one or more infographics gives students a way to approach the complex visual texts increasingly used in training.

  1. Select an infographic that is related to a theme or an occupational area. You can also choose a more general graphic (e.g., cold and flu).

  1. Provide a context for the graphic.

  1. Ask questions to activate background knowledge.

  1. Present information contained in the graphic in linear form and ask students to take notes; use common language to start.

  1. Display graphic and ask comprehension questions; ask for evidence.

  2. Ask students to work in pairs or small groups, taking turns being the teacher, who asks questions and requests evidence.

page.title: Presenting Information (Video or Mini-Lecture)
page.contents:
Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_3260.mp3

Audio Transcript


Students preparing for work and careers need more than just skills to be successful. That is true of both low-educated and more highly educated learners. All students need information about possible careers and the opportunity to discuss their goals and dreams in relation to career and training opportunities. You will see a couple of Department of Labor sites that offer comprehensive information. O*Net, the Occupational Information Network, is a free online database with hundreds of occupational definitions for teachers and materials developers.

Videos can help bring this information to life for students.

To persist to transition, English learners may also need proactive advising and assistance in navigating the work and training system. Students who lead turbulent lives may need access to support services. Those looking for work need access to a job developer who takes an active interest in them and advocates on their behalf with employers.

Most important, perhaps, students need support in seeing themselves as smart, capable adults who can reach both short- and long-term goals. Structuring classes so that students experience success every day and feel part of a community of learners who lend support and offer encouragement can go a long way in helping students develop self-efficacy and self-management skills associated with student success. The TED Talk offers some ideas for moving students from a mindset that says “I’m too old and I cannot learn” or “I’m not smart enough for a career” to “With every step and every class, I can get better.”

page.title: Career Exploration Resources
page.contents:
The Internet presents a treasure trove of materials you can review to build your curriculum. Here are a few examples:

1. Exploring Occupations and Careers

  • Integrating Career Awareness

  • http://lincs.ed.gov/professional-development/resource-collections/profile-246

  • College and Career Readiness Standards

2. Career related videos:

For close captioned videos on career clusters

3. To help students explore career possibilities related to their interests, try My Next Move. This is a DOL profiler that matches interests with careers; see www.mynextmove.org

4. You may want to increase your own background knowledge when it comes to the skill demands of particular jobs. One of the best resources for information on the skills, abilities and education required for particular jobs in a cluster is O*NET. You can then select a small number of jobs from a large data set to explore with your students. O*NET allows you to search by occupation or career cluster and lists typical job tasks and more; see www.onetonline.org

page.title: Scenario: Dealing with a Bad Day at Work
page.contents:
Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_3240.mp3

Audio Transcript


Stories told through graphics similar to those used in graphic novels are a great way to make language come alive and highlight cultural issues related to work and training., As a teacher of beginning-level learners, you can tell the stories orally while your students follow along on a screen or with handouts that only show the pictures. This approach gives you the opportunity to adapt the pace with which you tell the story and use paraphrasing to make unfamiliar phrases and new words comprehensible. Students can then be invited to retell the story in their own words (beginners can put the pictures in sequence) and either follow the original sequence to demonstrate understanding or create a story of their own.

Scenarios like “The Long Lunch” draw students’ attention to the message that tone conveys in English. English learners are often much more used to detecting grammar mistakes than they are to detecting differences in tone. Since sarcasm (“Nice job, dude”) and rhetorical questions (“What is wrong with you?”) are part of every communication in the United States, you do want to prepare your students for subtle messages in workplace communication that are conveyed through tone (e.g., if you are late to work, your supervisor’s asking, “Do you have any idea what time it is?” is not an information question).

You are integrating employability skills into a number of your courses and want to emphasize key cultural components such as calling in when you are late, being friendly, apologizing, and making amends when you make a mistake.

Bright Idea and Sample Lesson:

Use strip stories for problems at work or create a sequence on the board by using stick figures. Include cultural expectations in your story (e.g., “No, you cannot send your sister to work when you are sick.” “You cannot miss 5 days in a row because your car is broken.” “You must learn how to use the company’s online system to request vacation days.”).

Ask Yourself: What do I need to learn in order to create my own strip stories? What resources are available to me?  

Handouts:

page.title: Can-Do Post-Assessment
page.contents:
Now, reflect on your answers from the Pre-Assessment and consider the following statements again. Determine if they are No Problem, Sort of a Problem or Not at all a Problem.

Statement 1: I can create a plan for developing a curriculum that is contextualized to an occupational area.

Statement 2: I can develop several activities meant to activate students’ background knowledge.

Statement 3: I can devise activities that connect learner experiences to the skills needed in a particular pathway.

Statement 4: I can describe at least five peer-to-peer tasks that build the skills needed for work and training.

page.title: Final Reflection Questions
page.contents:
We know that good teachers are reflective teachers. Take a moment to think about what insights you have gained from this unit and how you might use the ideas.

1. What insights have you gained from this unit? What are your most important takeaways?

2. What steps, strategies, tips, or bright ideas do you think your program should implement?

3. What do you see as the next steps in developing your own contextualized course and infusing career content into instruction?

You can discuss question 2 with your Community of Practice, or with your colleagues on the LINCS discussion forum.
